**5 July – [[Sky Living Loves]] launches.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/digitaltv/news/a232419/vmtv-to-launch-living-loves-channel.html|title=VMtv to launch Living Loves channel|publisher=Digital Spy|date=24 June 2010}}</ref> The channel shows comedy and drama programmes that has recently aired on [[Sky Living]] and broadcasts each day between 3{{nbsp}}pm and 2{{nbsp}}am. ** 9 August – Sky Movies Classics HD launches.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skyprogrammeinformation.co.uk/download/September%20Sky%20Movies.pdf#page=2|title=SKY MOVIES CLASSICS GOES HD|publisher=Sky Programme Information|accessdate=17 July 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wT8gRyBg|archivedate=13 February 2011}}</ref> ** 23 August – [[Sky Sports News]] stops broadcasting on [[Freeview (UK)|Freeview]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://corporate.sky.com/page.aspx?pointerid=31fb93be272445fc96f0d9a59fb39145|title=Sky Sports News to get bigger and better as a pay TV channel|publisher=British Sky Broadcasting|date=17 June 2010}}</ref> and a HD version of the channel is launched.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skyprogrammeinformation.co.uk/download/Week%2034%20Sky%20Highlights.pdf#page=23|title=Programme Information Highlights|publisher=Sky Programme Information|accessdate=6 August 2010}}</ref> On Freeview, Sky Sports News is replaced by Sky 3 +1. ** 20 October – [[Sky Arts|Sky Arts 2]] launches.
*'''2011''' ** 1 February – ***[[Sky Atlantic]] launches.<ref name="Launch BSkyB">{{cite web|url=http://corporate.sky.com/page.aspx?pointerid=e9bfe9c2636c4ec28f66aea2494770f1|title=Sky Atlantic HD is new home of HBO & Mad Men|publisher=British Sky Broadcasting|date=1 October 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/ten/2011/0201/skyatlantic.html|title=Sky Atlantic to launch today|date=1 February 2011|work=RTÉ News|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> ***Living is renamed [[Sky Living]]. ** 28 February – [[Pick (TV channel)|Sky 3]] is rebranded as Pick TV. ** 6 July – Sky Anytime is merged with Sky Mobile and is rebranded as [[Sky Go]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://corporate.sky.com/media/press_releases/2011/Sky_TV_Goes_Online_and_Mobile_for_all_10%20million_customers.htm|title=Sky TV Goes Online and Mobile for all 10 million customers|publisher=British Sky Broadcasting|date=10 June 2011}}</ref> Key changes include the ability to watch live channels in line with your Sky TV subscription at no additional cost, limited to two simultaneous devices. **5 September – [[Sky Living Loves]] begins broadcasting 24 hours a day. ** October – The final edition of [[Sky Magazine]] is published.<ref>{{cite web|author=Gideon Spanier |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/business/markets/sky-axes-britains-biggest-magazine-6452719.html|title=Sky axes Britain's biggest magazine|work=London Evening Standard|date=12 October 2011|accessdate=12 November 2012}}</ref>
*'''2012''' ** 21 February – [[Sky Living Loves]] stops broadcasting. ** 9 March – [[Sky Sports F1]] launches. ** 12 November [[Sky One]] launches a +1 channel although for licensing reasons, ''[[The Simpsons]]'' is not broadcast on the timeshift channel.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/video/2012/aug/25/stuart-murphy-sky-launch-new-sky-channels-video|title=Sky's Stuart Murphy announces the launch of two new channels – video|author1=Andy Gallagher |author2=Josh Strauss |author3=Emily Brinnand |last-author-amp=yes |date=25 August 2012|work=[[guardian.co.uk]]|accessdate=26 August 2012}}</ref>
*'''2013''' ** 28 March – [[Sky Cinema|Sky Movies Disney]] is launched, effectively replacing [[Disney Cinemagic]].<ref name=gdn>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/feb/21/sky-movies-disney-new-channel-uk|title=Sky Movies Disney: new channel to show UK TV film premieres|publisher=The Guardian|date=21 February 2013}}</ref> ** 7 October – Pick TV is rebranded as [[Pick (TV channel)|Pick]].
*'''2014''' ** 12 August – ***[[Sky Sports|Sky Sports 5]] launches, primarily to broadcast European football.<ref>{{cite web|last=Rumsby |first=Ben |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/10888216/Sky-Sports-to-launch-new-European-football-channel.html |title=Sky Sports to launch new European football channel |publisher=The Telegraph |date=10 June 2014 |accessdate=10 June 2014}}</ref> ***[[Sky Sports News]] is rebranded Sky Sports News HQ. ** September – [[Sky Sports News Radio]] closes. ** 13 October – Following BSkyB's 2014 acquisition of [[Sky Italia]] and a majority 90.04% interest in [[Sky Deutschland]] in November 2014, its holding company British Sky Broadcasting Group plc changes its name to [[Sky plc]].<ref name="Sky plc">{{cite web|url=http://corporate.sky.com/media-centre/news-page/2014/sky-creates-europes-leading-entertainment-company |title=Sky creates Europe’s leading entertainment company |publisher=Sky |date=13 November 2014 |accessdate=13 November 2014}}</ref> The United Kingdom operations also changes the company name from British Sky Broadcasting Limited to Sky UK Limited, and still trades as Sky.
*'''2015''' ** 9 June – ***The two [[Sky Arts]] channels merge into a single service.<ref>{{cite web|last=Finbow |first=Katy |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a644682/sky-is-closing-one-of-its-arts-channels-to-make-a-single-super-channel.html |title=Sky is closing one of its Arts channels to make a single "super channel" |publisher=Digital Spy |date=29 April 2015 |accessdate=8 May 2015}}</ref> ***[[Sky 3D]] closes as a linear channel.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bradley-Jones |first=Luke |url=https://corporate.sky.com/media-centre/our-blog/2015/an-update-on-sky-3d |title=An update on Sky 3D |publisher=Sky plc |date=24 April 2015 |accessdate=20 August 2018}}</ref> ***Sky Livingit is rebranded as [[Real Lives (TV channel)|Real Lives]].
*'''2016''' ** 9 February – Sky Q prepares to launch as from this date customers can order Sky Q boxes. ** 15 June – Sky Movies is rebranded as [[Sky Cinema]].<ref name="guardian-skycinema">{{cite web|title=Sky Movies rebrand to feature one premiere a day|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/jun/15/sky-movies-cinema-star-wars-the-force-awakens|website=The Guardian|accessdate=26 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://recombu.com/digital/article/sky-movies-is-changing-with-a-new-name-and-better-picture-quality|title=Sky Movies is changing to Sky Cinema, but what has really changed? |publisher=Recombu.com|date=15 June 2016}}</ref> ** 13 August – [[Sky Sports]] broadcasts its first event in [[Ultra-high-definition television|UHD]]. ** 24 August – [[Sky Sports|Sky Sports Mix]] launches. It is available to all Sky customers, and is designed to offer a sampling of content from the full range of Sky Sports networks to non-Sky Sports customers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/sky-sports-to-launch-new-channel-which-will-offer-free-premier-league-matches-34552857.html|title=Sky Sports to launch new channel which will offer free Premier League matches|work=The Independent|access-date=18 July 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/more-sports/news/12040/10543289/new-channel-sky-sports-mix-to-launch-on-wednesday|title=New channel Sky Sports Mix launches today|work=Sky Sports|access-date=18 July 2017|language=en}}</ref>
*'''2017''' ** 4 January – [[Sky Box Office|Sky Cinema Box Office]] closes. ** 18 July – [[Sky Sports]] is revamped with the numbered channels being replaced by sports-specific channels. These include two channels dedicated to football, a cricket channel and a golf channel. Other sports are moved to two new channels – Action and Arena – and a showcase channel called Sky Sports Main Event is launched which features simulcasts of the top events being show on Sky Sports that day. <ref name="guardian-newsky17">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2017/jun/27/sky-sports-channels-prices-football-golf-cricket|title=Sky Sports to replace numbered channels and slash prices in revamp|last=Sweney|first=Mark|date=27 June 2017|work=The Guardian|access-date=28 June 2017|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> Also, [[Sky Sports News]] drops the HQ label.
*'''2018''' ** 23 January – [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]]'s £11.7bn bid to take full control of [[Sky UK|Sky]] is provisionally blocked by the [[Competition and Markets Authority]] (CMA) amid concerns of plurality.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/jan/23/rupert-murdoch-sky-bid-blocked-21st-century-fox-cma|title=Rupert Murdoch's Sky bid provisionally blocked by regulator|accessdate=23 January 2018|publisher=The Guardian|date=23 January 2018}}</ref> ** 14 February – [[BT Group|BT]] and [[Sky UK|Sky]] have agreed a £4.4bn three-year deal to show live Premiership football matches from 2019 to 2022, but the amount falls short of the £5.1bn deal struck in 2015.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-43052024 |title=Premier League raises less from TV rights auction |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=14 February 2018 |accessdate=14 February 2018}}</ref> ** 27 February – US cable TV giant [[Comcast]] makes a £22.1bn bid for [[Sky UK|Sky]], challenging the existing offer from [[21st Century Fox]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-43209100|title=Rupert Murdoch's Sky bid challenged by Comcast|publisher=BBC|work=BBC News|date=27 February 2018|accessdate=27 February 2018}}</ref> ** 30 April – Sky announces that its horse racing channel [[At the Races]] will become fully part of the [[Sky Sports]] network and will be rebranded as 'Sky Sports Racing' on or before 1 January 2019.<ref>[http://sport-onthebox.com/2018/04/30/sky-sports-racing-to-replace-at-the-races-by-2019/ Sky Sports Racing to replace At the Races]</ref>. ** 6 August – [[Sky Living]] is rebranded as 'Sky Witness', bringing an end to the ''Living'' brand after 25 years.<ref>[https://www.a516digital.com/2018/06/sky-living-to-become-sky-witness.html Sky Living to become Sky Witness] a516digital, 8 June 2018</ref>. ** 26 September – 21st Century Fox announces it will sell its 39% stake in [[Sky UK]] to Comcast, ending [[Rupert Murdoch]]'s three decade association with the broadcaster.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-45654792 |title=Rupert Murdoch ends Sky association with Comcast stake sale |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=26 September 2018 |accessdate=26 September 2018}}</ref>

'''UK Resistance''' (also written as '''UK:Resistance''', or simply '''UK:R''') was a [[video game]]s website founded in 1996 by Gary Cutlack and Jon M (under the pseudonyms Commander Zorg and Captain Jax). Originally a [[Sega]] news and reviews fansite, UK Resistance expanded its coverage across all formats, and developed a style depending more on satirical updates rather than its original UK news and reviews content. The site officially closed on March 29, 2011<ref>.{{cite web|url=http://www.ukresistance.co.uk/2011/03/closedown-march-29th-2011/|title=CLOSEDOWN, MARCH 29th 2011 |author=UK:Resistance|date=2011-03-29|accessdate=2011-03-29|publisher=Gary Cutlack}}</ref>
The website is frequently referenced by games industry media, and its exposure led to a writer's position at ''[[Sega Saturn Magazine]]'' for Gary Cutlack.<ref>{{cite journal| title=Rings of Saturn| journal=[[Retro Gamer]]| author=[[Damien McFerran]]| date=Christmas 2007| issue=45| pages=86–91}}</ref> The website has been described by ''[[Edge (magazine)|Edge]]'' as the place where "Europe's Sega cognoscenti gathered to discuss the burning issues of the day",<ref>{{cite journal|title=Requiem for a Dream: The Life and Death of Dreamcast|journal=[[Edge (magazine)|Edge]]|author=Edge staff|date=Christmas 2001|issue=105|pages=49–54}}</ref> and by ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' gaming blog as "the popular taking-on-the-industry slam page".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.wired.com/games/2006/03/uk_resistance_u.html|title=UK Resistance, US Resistance, Sega Ads|author=[[Chris Kohler]]|date=2006-03-09|accessdate=2007-02-03|publisher=''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]''}}</ref> The site was often linked to from other gaming [[blogs]] such as [[Kotaku]] and [[Joystiq]].
Notable updates from the website include the '''Blue Sky in Games''' campaign, a campaign to reintroduce light hearted environments and settings into video games, as opposed to the prevalence of "realistic" [[gang violence]] games such as ''[[Saints Row]]''. As UK Resistance themselves put it, "We want to play in a HAPPY PRETEND LAND, not a shit version of an American slum full of mixed-race gangsters wearing licensed sportswear!". The campaign was picked up by websites such as [[Eurogamer]], who gave it their full backing,<ref>{{cite web|title=Bring blue skies back to games!|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/article.php?article_id=61700|author=Ellie Gibson|date=2005-11-15|publisher=[[Eurogamer]]|accessdate=2007-02-03}}</ref> and ''[[PC Zone]]'', who called the campaign "a just cause... that we heartily endorse".<ref>{{cite web|title = Crime Life: Gang Wars review|url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/article.php?id=132231|author=PC Zone staff|date=2006-01-11|publisher=[[PC Zone]]|accessdate=2007-02-03}}</ref>
UK Resistance was acquired by [[Shiny Media]] in June 2007,<ref>{{cite web|title=Shiny welcomes Gary Cutlack of UK Resistance fame| url=http://www.shinymedia.com/2007/06/shiny-welcomes-.html| author=Ashley Norris, Gary Cutlack| publisher=Shiny Media| date=2007-06-29| accessdate=2007-12-19}}</ref> before being returned to the sole ownership of Cutlack in June 2008 in lieu of money owed to him by Shiny.<ref>{{cite web|title=Shiny media has gone bust| url=http://www.ukresistance.co.uk/2009/07/shiny-media-has-gone-bust/| author=UK:Resistance| publisher=Gary Cutlack| date=2009-07-22| accessdate=2009-07-26}}</ref> In October 2007, UK Resistance was voted Best Non-Commercial Website or Blog at the inaugural Games Media Awards held at the [[Soho#Raymond Revuebar|Soho Revue Bar]] in [[London]]. Cutlack was also nominated for Best Writer In Specialist Media at the same event.<ref>{{cite web| title=Games Media Awards finalists revealed| url=http://www.mcvuk.com/news/28177/Games-Media-Awards-finalists-revealed| author=MCV Staff| publisher=[[Market for Home Computing and Video Games|MCV]]| date=2007-08-31| accessdate=2007-12-19| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070913162151/http://www.mcvuk.com/news/28177/Games-Media-Awards-finalists-revealed| archivedate=2007-09-13| df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title=2007 Games Media Awards results| url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/content_page.php?aid=29519| author=GamesIndustry.biz Staff| publisher=[[GamesIndustry.biz]]| date=2007-10-12| accessdate=2007-12-19}}</ref>

[[File:Wiere Brothers in Rosalinda..jpg|thumb|The Wiere Brothers appeared as Frish, Frosh, and Frush in Rosalinda, Los Angeles Civic Light Opera, 1968-69. ]] The '''Wiere Brothers''' were a comedy team who appeared in 1930s and 1940s films, and as live performers from the 1920s to the late 1960s.
==History== The names of the three brothers were: * '''Harry Wiere''', (23 June 1906 in [[Berlin]], [[German Empire]] – 15 January 1992) * '''Herbert Wiere''', (27 February 1908 in [[Vienna]], [[Austria-Hungary]] – 5 August 1999) * '''Sylvester Wiere''', (17 September 1909 in [[Prague]], [[Austria-Hungary]] – 7 July 1970)
[[File:Wiere brothers 1962.JPG|thumb|200px|From left: Sylvester, Herbert, and Harry from their 1962 television show, ''Oh, Those Bells!''.]] The Wiere Brothers were vaudeville performers who occasionally appeared in films and television. Their films include ''Hands Across the Border'' in 1944 with [[Roy Rogers]], ''[[Road to Rio]]'' in 1947 with [[Bob Hope]] and [[Bing Crosby]], and [[Double Trouble (1967 film)|''Double Trouble'']] in 1967 as three detectives on the hunt for [[Elvis Presley]]. In 1962, the Wiere Brothers had their own [[television series]] called, ''[[Oh! Those Bells]]'', that aired on [[CBS]]. The show was created by [[Jules White]] who had previously directed [[the Three Stooges]], [[Buster Keaton]] and [[Andy Clyde]] in short-subject films for [[Columbia Pictures]]. ''Oh! Those Bells'' included a lot of [[slapstick]] comedy but only 13 episodes were aired. The team was still appearing on television in 1970 on shows such as ''[[The Merv Griffin Show]]'' and ''[[Laugh-In]]'' and were still touring the same year. But after Sylvester's death in July 1970, Harry and Herbert Wiere discontinued their act.<ref name="lastyear">{{cite book | first=Leonard | last=Maltin | authorlink= | coauthors= | year=1970 | title=Movie Comedy Teams | publisher=Signet Book | location=New York, NY | page= 331 | isbn= 0-451-04453-3 | oclc= 475688500}}</ref> Harry Wiere did make one appearance on the TV series ''[[The Bionic Woman|Bionic Woman]]'' in 1976 as the Tipsy Man.
One of their popular acts of the 1960s involved the three brothers playing the [[violin]], [[guitar]] and [[bass fiddle]], and Mildred Seymour, their accompanist, performing a classical piece on the grand piano. Herbert would try to do a serious number on the violin but would get frustrated with his brothers' [[hillbilly]] antics. With a shrug, Herbert would stop playing and decide to balance the violin on his chin. Harry would then notice Herbert's accomplishment and would take the guitar and balance it on his chin. This left Sylvester smiling blandly at the audience, still plucking his bass fiddle. When Sylvester sees Herbert and Harry balancing their instruments on their chins, he would do a long take, turning from his brothers to his huge bass fiddle and then back at them. Then, finally Sylvester would lift the bass fiddle in the air and balance it on his chin for the finale.<ref name="chinbalancing">{{cite book | first=Leonard | last=Maltin | authorlink= | coauthors= | year=1970 | title=Movie Comedy Teams | publisher=Signet Book | location=New York, NY | pages= 330–331 | isbn= 0-451-04453-3 | oclc= 475688500}}</ref> The Wiere Brothers stage performances offered a unique blend of classical European musical tradition transitioning to the spirit of American western culture with comedic flare delighting audiences around the world. They performed four command performances for the queen of England.
[[Inga Wiere]], a sister of Herbert, Harry and Sylvester Wiere, was married to dancer [[Jon Zerby]]. Together they were known as The Dancing Zerbys, a successful nightclub act in the 1940s and 1950s. Actress and dancer [[Kim Darby]] is their daughter.
